etymologies: 1940s; earliest use found in Kenneth Pike (1912–2000). From voc- + -oid

definitions: A speech sound articulated with no obstruction of the airstream; a vocalic speech sound.

notes.text: Coined by the American linguist Kenneth Pike in order to refer specifically to a vowel as defined phonetically (by the way in which it is articulated), rather than a vowel as a phonological unit.

definitions: Of or relating to a vocoid or vocoids; designating a vocoid.
